Composition was not easy sor him;1 and he wrote in verse simply to make his doctrine more palatable to those whom it was intended to deliver.² Here then is a character of singular moral strength, that for the good of men set before himself the great task of revealing the truth,-— ‘the way of life.'8

N evertheless Lucretius was not one that moved much among ’ men in their daily walks. He does not speak of the Forum, the busy streets, the centres of interest in the life and society of Rome, so often referred to by the Latin poets. He knew well the pleasures of contemplation. When he speaks of the struggle for office, the ambitions and passions of the mass of mankind,⁴ it is in the manner osone who views these things from a distance, who in a life ofretirement grieves at the folly

⁴ of those that never find true happiness.⁵ Still he was by no

means ignorant of human nature nor indifferent to the issues of his time.
